title: SSZ cannot compile to target `wasm32-unknown-unknown`
body:
## Present Behaviour

There appears to be two main issues:
1. The `hashing` crate depends on `ring`, which does not compile to WebAssembly due to its reliance on custom assembly: https://github.com/briansmith/ring/issues/657#issuecomment-396416821
2. There are a couple places where a 64-bit architecture is assumed, but wasm only supports 32-bit [at this time](https://github.com/rust-lang/rustup.rs/issues/1661#issuecomment-475829289). Here are the specific lines I see having issues:

https://github.com/sigp/lighthouse/blob/20b7bdda4a4bda304321b356b1f4d48f9bf8aa58/eth2/utils/ssz/src/decode/impls.rs#L37

https://github.com/sigp/lighthouse/blob/20b7bdda4a4bda304321b356b1f4d48f9bf8aa58/eth2/utils/ssz/src/lib.rs#L49

## Expected Behaviour

It would be great if this compiled to the `wasm32-unknown-unknown` target as that will allow us to use the crate for developing execution environments.

## Steps to resolve

### Issue 1
I ran some benchmarks to determine the performance tradeoff on the `hashing` library when using the WebAssembly compatible `sha2` crate vs. `ring`. Here are the results when `ring` is used (the change is against the `sha2` variant):

```console
> cargo bench

                        time:   [325.42 us 327.53 us 329.65 us]

                        Performance has improved.
Found 8 outliers among 100 measurements (8.00%)
  6 (6.00%) high mild
  2 (2.00%) high severe

vec_of_8196_struct/from_ssz_bytes
                        time:   [184.88 us 186.16 us 187.75 us]
                        change: [-5.8797% -4.2776% -2.8292%] (p = 0.00 < 0.05)
```

`ring` is clearly more performant, so I believe the best route here is to add a compiler flag to only use the `sha2` crate when compiling to a `wasm32` target.

### Issue 2
I'm open to suggestions here. For the `impl`, I think a compiler flag for [pointer widths](https://doc.rust-lang.org/reference/conditional-compilation.html#target_pointer_width) of 32 and 64 would be adequate. I'm not sure of a good solution for fixing `MAX_LENGTH_VALUE` besides using the same compiler flag or just hardcoding the value in.
